results.title: Europe Looks at Italy’s Meloni With Caution and Trepidation
results.abstract: Giorgia Meloni, poised to be the country’s first far-right leader since Mussolini, says she supports Ukraine and has moderated her harsh views on Europe, but there are doubts, given her partners.

multimedia.caption: Giorgia Meloni leaving the polling station where she voted in Rome on Sunday. Her Brothers of Italy received the highest vote total of any single party, according to preliminary results.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: 4 Years After Thrilling Cave Rescue, Sleepy Park Readies for Onslaught
results.abstract: An unheralded national park in Thailand was the center of global attention when 12 boys were trapped in a cave there. In the wake of major movies about the rescue, the park expects a visitor surge.
results.byline: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono

multimedia.caption: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.
multimedia.copyright: Luke Duggleby for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.
multimedia.copyright: Luke Duggleby for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.

results.title: At Least 15 Killed in School Shooting in Russia, Including Children
results.abstract: An unidentified gunman entered a school in the city of Izhevsk, killing four adults and 11 children, according to federal investigators.

multimedia.caption: Police and paramedics working at the scene of a shooting at school No. 88 in Izhevsk, Russia, on Monday.
Police and paramedics working at the scene of a shooting at school No. 88 in Izhevsk, Russia, on Monday.
Police and paramedics working at the scene of a shooting at school No. 88 in Izhevsk, Russia, on Monday.

results.title: Key Takeaways From Italy’s Landmark Election
results.abstract: Giorgia Meloni, leader of the hard-right Brothers of Italy, looked set to become prime minister after her party garnered more votes than any other.

multimedia.caption: Giorgia Meloni holding a sign reading “Thank you Italy” at a news conference on Monday. She is almost certain to become Italy’s first female prime minister.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: Victorious Meloni Faces Early Test of Italy’s Resolve on Russia
results.abstract: The hard-right leader Giorgia Meloni has been a full-throated supporter of Ukraine, but her coalition partners have sounded like apologists for Vladimir V. Putin.

multimedia.caption: Giorgia Meloni on Monday after early projections had her coalition winning a majority in Italy’s Parliament. She has unambiguously criticized Russia’s aggression in Ukraine.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: Iran Strikes Kurdish Separatist Groups in Northern Iraq
results.abstract: The death of a young Iranian Kurdish woman in police custody has set off an intense wave of protests across Iran over the past 10 days, igniting fury particularly in the country’s Kurdish minority community.
results.byline: By Cora Engelbrecht and Jane Arraf

multimedia.caption: Women protesting the killing of Mahsa Amini in Erbil, the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq, on Saturday.
Women protesting the killing of Mahsa Amini in Erbil, the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq, on Saturday.
Women protesting the killing of Mahsa Amini in Erbil, the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq, on Saturday.

results.title: Death of Iranian Woman Ignites Fury Among Fellow Kurds
results.abstract: The protests that have swept Iran following the death of a woman in police custody have been especially intense in the country’s minority Kurdish population.
results.byline: By Jane Arraf and Farnaz Fassihi
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Protesters in Erbil, the capital of Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan Region, burning an Iranian flag on Saturday.
Protesters in Erbil, the capital of Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan Region, burning an Iranian flag on Saturday.

results.title: Deadlier Than the Titanic: A Ferry Set Out With About 1,900 Aboard. Only 64 Survived.
results.abstract: Tourists, vendors, babies, hundreds of university students and a soccer team from Senegal perished in a little-known ferry disaster 20 years ago. Survivors and families of victims still want justice.

multimedia.caption: The Kantene cemetery in Ziguinchor, Senegal, has 42 graves of victims of the wreck. Artists paid tribute to the deceased by painting on the walls this year.
multimedia.copyright: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

results.title: Two Cities, Two Armies: Pivot Points in the Fight in Ukraine’s East
results.abstract: The battle for the critical Donbas region in Ukraine is centered on two strategically important cities: Lyman, held by the Russians, and Bakhmut, held by Ukraine. The fighting over the cities is fierce as both armies race to claim new ground.
results.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

multimedia.caption: A soldier walked across the remains of one of the main bridges in Bakhmut, Ukraine. The bridge was destroyed in September as Russian forces shelled the city.
A soldier walked across the remains of one of the main bridges in Bakhmut, Ukraine. The bridge was destroyed in September as Russian forces shelled the city.
A soldier walked across the remains of one of the main bridges in Bakhmut, Ukraine. The bridge was destroyed in September as Russian forces shelled the city.

results.title: Edward Snowden Is Granted Russian Citizenship
results.abstract: Mr. Snowden, a former intelligence contractor, left the United States after giving hundreds of highly classified N.S.A. documents to The Guardian and The Washington Post in 2013.

multimedia.caption: Edward Snowden speaking during an online forum in Moscow last year.
Edward Snowden speaking during an online forum in Moscow last year.
Edward Snowden speaking during an online forum in Moscow last year.

results.title: A ‘Nightmare’ for Forecasters: Here’s Why Hurricanes Are Getting Stronger, Faster
results.abstract: Storms that intensify quickly and unpredictably present a big problem for public safety officials, who have less time to assess threats.

multimedia.caption: A firefighter in Bourg, La., during Hurricane Ida last year. Wind speeds in the storm rose to 150 miles per hour, from 85 m.p.h., in less than 24 hours.
A firefighter in Bourg, La., during Hurricane Ida last year. Wind speeds in the storm rose to 150 miles per hour, from 85 m.p.h., in less than 24 hours.

results.title: The Dollar Is Strong. That Is Good for the U.S. but Bad for the World.
results.abstract: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.

multimedia.caption: When it comes to global finance and trade, the United States has outsize influence.

results.title: Ukrainian Soldier Whose Bracelet Made Him a Symbol Gets Posthumous Honors
results.abstract: Serhiy Sova, 36, was honored as a Hero of Ukraine by President Volodymyr Zelensky. His body was found in a mass grave in Izium.

multimedia.caption: Serhiy Sova, whose body was exhumed in Izium earlier this month, in 2019. He was a trainer and breeder of dogs.
Serhiy Sova, whose body was exhumed in Izium earlier this month, in 2019. He was a trainer and breeder of dogs.

results.title: Putin Ally Acknowledges Founding Wagner Mercenary Group
results.abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, a Russian businessman and close associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, confirmed his role weeks after he was seen in a recruitment video for the private military company.

multimedia.caption: Yevgeny Prigozhin at a meeting of Russian and Turkish government officials and business leaders in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in 2016.
Yevgeny Prigozhin at a meeting of Russian and Turkish government officials and business leaders in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in 2016.

results.abstract: Times reporters make sense of what’s happening.

results.title: For China’s Auto Market, Electric Isn’t the Future. It’s the Present.
results.abstract: More electric cars will be sold in the country this year than in the rest of the world combined, as its domestic market accelerates ahead of the global competition.
results.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

multimedia.caption: BYD, China’s largest electric vehicle maker, displayed cars at an auto show in Wuhan, China, in July.
BYD, China’s largest electric vehicle maker, displayed cars at an auto show in Wuhan, China, in July.

results.title: TikTok Seen Moving Toward U.S. Security Deal, but Hurdles Remain
results.abstract: A draft agreement with the Biden administration to keep the Chinese-owned video app operating in the United States is under review. That could mean more wrangling.
results.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, David McCabe, Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush
org_facet: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

multimedia.caption: TikTok has been under a legal cloud in the United States because of its Chinese ownership.

results.title: Monkeypox Appears to Recede, but Risks and Uncertainties Linger
results.abstract: Scientists do not yet know how well the vaccine and the drug used to treat the infection are working. Two new trials will provide answers.

multimedia.caption: Workers prepare the Jynneos monkeypox vaccine at a vaccination site in Los Angeles last month. Though cases seem to be receding, recent reports suggest that a single dose may not be protective enough.

Workers prepare the Jynneos monkeypox vaccine at a vaccination site in Los Angeles last month. Though cases seem to be receding, recent reports suggest that a single dose may not be protective enough.

results.title: To Defend Democracy, Is Brazil’s Top Court Going Too Far?
results.abstract: Brazil’s Supreme Court has acted as the primary check on President Jair Bolsonaro’s power. Now many are worried the court is posing its own threat.
results.byline: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

multimedia.caption: Judge Alexandre de Moraes, a member of Brazil’s Supreme Court, has used the court’s power to counter the antidemocratic stances of President Jair Bolsonaro and his supporters.
Judge Alexandre de Moraes, a member of Brazil’s Supreme Court, has used the court’s power to counter the antidemocratic stances of President Jair Bolsonaro and his supporters.

results.title: U.S. Warns Russia of ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ if It Uses Nuclear Weapons
results.abstract: The comments by the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, illustrate how quickly the rhetoric has intensified as Russia has faltered on the battlefield in recent months.
results.byline: By David E. Sanger and Jim Tankersley

multimedia.caption: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, this month. American intelligence officials say they still believe the chances that nuclear weapons will be used in the conflict are low.

results.title: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
results.abstract: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.

multimedia.caption: A polling station in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Saturday, the second day of a referendum on joining the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic to Russia.

results.abstract: Plus anger builds in Japan over Shinzo Abe’s state funeral and Russia tries to conscript Ukrainians.

results.abstract: In online exchanges with Ukraines first lady, the Pink Floyd co-founder said Ukraine should seek peace with Russia and blamed the United States for encouraging the conflict.

results.title: ‘They are not happy with how we love each other’: Gay parents fear a Meloni victory.
results.abstract: In her election campaign, Giorgia Meloni pledged to oppose surrogacy and adoption by gay couples.

results.title: Soviet Monuments Become Latest Target of Backlash Against War in Ukraine
results.abstract: Across Eastern and Central Europe, statues honoring Soviet troops for their role in defeating the Nazis in World War II have in recent weeks come down or been slated for demolition.

results.title: Ukraine warns of growing attacks by drones Iran has supplied to Russia.
results.abstract: As Moscow finds itself isolated internationally, and as its arsenal has been depleted in Ukraine, it has turned for military support to countries including Iran.

multimedia.caption: An unmanned aerial vehicle seen on Friday over the southern port city of Odesa, where Ukrainian officials say Russia has repeatedly deployed Iranian-made drones.

results.title: Germany’s Chancellor Has ‘a Lot’ for Ukraine. But No Battle Tanks.
results.abstract: Military assistance to Kyiv has become something of a litmus test of Olaf Scholz’s ability to lead Europe through its most significant security crisis since World War II.

multimedia.caption: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany last week at the United Nations in New York. “Leadership does not mean you do what people ask you,” he said.

results.title: Hello, fellow kids: Italian politicians turn to TikTok for votes.
results.abstract: Lawmakers set up TikTok accounts to try to reach undecided voters before Sunday’s elections. Hilarity ensued.

multimedia.caption: Silvio Berlusconi’s TikTok profile is brimming with jokes, clips from TV appearances and videos shot in a studio.
